_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The City of Glendale Water & Power has a corporate structure to assist Grayson Power Plant with compliance issues associated with release prevention and safety issues. The Grayson Power Plant is committed to providing a safe work environment for its employees. Section Safety Supervisors are tasked with the implementation of the safety programs and policies at the Plant. In addition, the Power Plant has an Accident Review Committee that is responsible for reviewing all incidents and near misses that occur at the facility. This group is responsible for collecting all necessary information from employees (and contractors as necessary) regarding a reported incident through interview sessions. Following the data collection, the Accident Review Committee will meet to hypothesize potential causes and develop mitigation measures to prevent future occurrences.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The chlorine systems for  the Grayson Power Plant of City of Glendale Water and Power are located at 634 Bekins Way, Glendale, California 91201.  The chlorine systems for the Grayson Power Plant consist of chlorine one-ton containers which are the storage vessels.  Chlorine gas is drawn from a one ton container through a vacuum regulator to the chlorinators.  Still under vacuum from the chlorinators, it is drawn to injectors and mixed with water from the treatment processes.  

A maximum of 5 one ton chlorine containers (10,000 lbs) are maintained at the Grayson Power Plant: one (2,000 lbs) at the No. 1 Chlorine House and four (8,000 lbs) at  the No. 2 Chlorine House. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

City of Glendale Water and Power has a Process Safety Management program in place to manage the handling of chlorine.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practic

es outlined by the Chlorine Institute.  In addition to the Management Programs, there is a chlorine gas detector in the storage room that is set to activate a visual/audible alarm at 3 ppm. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Based on the Hazard Assessment Update (May 2004), which conducted a review of the accident history during the last five years (May 1999 through May 2004), the City of Glendale Water and Power's Grayson Power Plant has not had an accidental release of chlorine. There was a near miss on May 7, 2004 that involved the chlorine delivery vendor. During a delivery, the chlorine vendor did not follow his procedure and a one ton container rolled off the truck. No chlorine was released and no one was injured. The incident investigation team reviewed the incident and consulted with all applicable employees regarding the delivery vendor's procedures. The delivery vendor was also notified of the incident.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The City of Glendale Water and Power has an emergency response plan in effect at the facility.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives: 

1.)To save lives.
2.)To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.)To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. 

The Plan also includes the Emergency training for all City of Glendale Water and Power employees. The City of Glendale Water and Power performs periodic emergency evacuation drills to enhance the emergency response skills of its personnel.

The Emergency Response Plan is reviewed and updated by the City of Glendale Water and Power responsible person at least once a year.  This Plan has been reviewed and updated to ensure comp

liance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, and to ensure that the plan is kept current.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Grayson Power Plant has conducted a PSM/RMP Compliance Audit (May 2004) and revalidated the Process Hazard Analysis (May 2004). Both studies resulted in minor procedural modifications to ensure a safe operation. These modifications are currently being implemented with an expected date of completion being June 1, 2005. The Power Systems Analyst and the Power Plant Operations Supervisor are responsible for ensuring that these recommendations are implemented. 

In addition to the mitigation measures included in the Compliance Audit and Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation, the Process Safety Management team continues to ensure employee involvement in Safety Plan Development and training requirement protocol.
